lines.text: Enter COUNTESS and Clown

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Come on, sir I shall now put you to the height of your breeding.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught: I know my business is but to the court.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: To the court! why, what place make you special, when you put off that with such contempt But to the court!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he may easily put it off at court: he that cannot make a leg, put offs cap, kiss his hand and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the court but for me, I have an answer will serve all men.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Marry, thats a bountiful answer that fits all questions.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: It is like a barbers chair that fits all buttocks, the pinbuttock, the quatchbuttock, the brawn buttock, or any buttock.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Will your answer serve fit to all questions

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney, as your French crown for your taffeta punk, as Tibs rush for Toms forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a morris for Mayday, as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding queen to a wrangling knave, as the nuns lip to the friars mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for all questions

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: From below your duke to beneath your constable, it will fit any question.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit all demands.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned should speak truth of it: here it is, and all that belongs tot. Ask me if I am a courtier: it shall do you no harm to learn.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I pray you, sir, are you a courtier

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O Lord, sir! Theres a simple putting off. More, more, a hundred of them.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me tot, I warrant you.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O Lord, sir! spare not me.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Do you cry, O Lord, sir! at your whipping, and spare not me Indeed your O Lord, sir! is very sequent to your whipping: you would answer very well to a whipping, if you were but bound tot.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I neer had worse luck in my life in my O Lord, sir! I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: I play the noble housewife with the time To entertaint so merrily with a fool.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O Lord, sir! why, theret serves well again.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: An end, sir to your business. Give Helen this, And urge her to a present answer back: Commend me to my kinsmen and my son: This is not much.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Not much commendation to them.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Not much employment for you: you understand me

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Haste you again.
Exeunt severally
